ANAEROBIC PROCESS MONITORING USING NEURAL NETWORKS AND FUZZY LOGIC
FABIANO SUTTER DE OLIVEIRA
Orientadores:

In Brazil there are several wastewater treatments plants that employ anaerobic digestion, due to the efficient and high removal of organic load and low energy consumption. However, anaerobic processes are complex and depend on various biochemical reactions promoted by different microorganisms. This work aims to employ two artificial intelligence methodologies (artificial neural network and fuzzy logic) to predict biogas production and the behavior of anaerobic reactors, respectively. Biogas is the main prod uct of anaerobic digestion and is important for electricity generation and cogeneration. The proposed methodology compares responses from different prediction models to estimate biogas production found in the literature with responses from supervised neura l network, considered smarter when compared to classical methodologies. For this comparison proposal, the Brazil -Germany Project to Promote Energy Use of Biogas (PROBIOGAS) was used as a source of field measurements. After these tests with different topolo gies, the final results, when compared with actual measurements proved that the use of the neural network was very promising. The best configuration of RNA and its weights, after the training and testing phases, reaching to minimize the error function pres ented R2 equal to 84.5 and 91.3, respectively. The standard deviations between the actual measurements and neural networks were 1.76, while other methodologies presented differences well above (e.g. UNFCC and actual measurement was 5.80 and UNFCC and neura l network was 5.50). The results showed that all classical methodologies showed considerable dispersion among themselves and when compared with the actual measurements; however, the dispersion obtained between the real values and the neural network was muc h smaller. The architecture used was able to generalize the results, concluding that the application of a set of values unknown to the training produced a set of desired outputs of biogas production very close to reality. Another aspect of the study involv ed the modeling of physically separated anaerobic reactors on a real scale based on fuzzy logic. Two Maria JosÃ© de O. C. GuimarÃ£es D.Sc. EstevÃ£o Freire D.Sc.

fuzzy inference modules were developed to predict the efficiency of anaerobic reactors. The results showed that anaerobic reactors behave differently, theo retically under the same operating conditions. It was also able to describe scenarios, in which the reactor may be working or not within the expected performance (70%). In addition, the present work suggests some possible causes and actions to improve reac tor efficiency that will help and support the operational team to correct failures in real time. The modeling proposed an approach to better understand the anaerobic process in reactors using only fuzzy logic, replacing other more complex models found in the literature and which are also indicated for the modeling of UASB reactors. The validation of the model (R2) was 0.8636 corroborating a significant correlation between the efficiency results, calculated by the classical methodology and the fuzzy model ou tputs.
Keywords: wastewater treatment, anaerobic process, UASB reactors, neural network, fuzzy logic,
